newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Taiwan oil imports doubtful despite refinery fire.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan oil imports doubtful despite refinery fire.

text.p: Taiwan's 200,000-barrel-per-day Taoyuan refinery does not currently expect to import oil products to cover losses from a fire-damaged unit, an official from the Chinese Petroleum Corp (CPC) said on Friday.
However, much will depend on how long the residue hydro-sulphuriser, damaged by fire and an explosion late on Thursday, will be down.

The 15,000-barrel-per-day (bpd) unit, which cuts fuel oil sulphur content to 0.5 percent, was due to restart operations on Thursday after a routine annual maintenance when it was struck by the fire and explosion. The maintenance began in early May.
The official said the damage to the unit was not very serious but CPC must delay the restart in order to conduct safety checks as required by the government.
Other CPC officials had estimated that the damaged unit's restart could be delayed for up to one month.
The official said Taiwan has four other residue hydro-desulphurisers. Taoyuan has one other similar unit, with a capacity of 30,000 bpd.
Taiwan's only other refinery, the 570,000-bpd Kaohsiung complex, has three residue hydro-desulphurisers, each with a capacity of 30,000 bpd.
Officials said the units would be able to cover for any shortages during the delay in the restart.
"The refinery is still evaluating the impact to (fuel oil) production and so far there has been no call for purchasing requirements from the refinery," the official said.

CPC currently has a tender to buy two 38,000-tonne cargoes of 0.5-percent sulphur fuel oil for July deliveries, which was issued on May 28, a day before the fire occurred. The tender closes on June 4 and is valid for two days.
The official said the delay would not have much impact on output of other products.
Swaps fuel oil prices in Singapore gained about 75 cents for June to be quoted at $100.50/$101.00 per tonne, while July gained $1.25 at $99.50/$100.25.
But traders said the firmer tone was due to higher bids by a Singapore trader rather than the fire at Taoyuan which was largely ignored.
